Reviews.Title: Comments Actually Pertaining to this Specific TV Model
Reviews.Author: W
Reviews.Content: I decided to buy LG's (well-reviewed) 42LK520 at the exact time it was discontinued and no longer available. That's what I get for procrastinating. The replacement for 2011's 42LK520 is 2012's 42CS570. On paper, the basic specifications are almost the same as the 42LK520. Since new-model reviews aren't available yet, I had no reason to not get the 42CS570 given the similarities.The owner's manual available from LG's support website details the inputs, outputs, and menu options available on the TV. The manual appears to be accurate and only covers the 42CS570 and 47CS570 models (ie - not too much "depends on model" content). Specifications are finally up on LG's product page, though they still have some errors. For instance, they only list one rear AV input. In fact, there is also a second, side AV input.The 42CS570 is a 42-inch, 1080P, 120Hz, LCD TV listed for $699.99. The screen has a 16:9 aspect ratio and a 150,000:1 contrast ratio. On the rear panel, there are 2 HDMI, 2 Component, 1 AV (Composite), 1 RGB (PC), 1 Antenna / Cable (RF), and 1 Audio (RGB / DVI) inputs, with 1 Optical Audio output. On the side panel, there are: 1 USB, 1 HDMI, and 1 AV (Composite) inputs, with 1 Headphone Audio output. The channel, volume, and other controls are touch-sensitive areas on the front of the TV.The TruMotion menu option has two components: De-Judder and De-Blur. Both components take a value between 0 and 10. There are three pre-set options: Off (0, 0), Low (3, 3), High (7, 7). A fourth option, User, allows for either component to be set to preference. The TV comes with a power-saving / screen-dimming feature turned On. At night, I actually thought this was sort of nice. During the day I turned the feature Off. Otherwise, I thought the picture settings out-of-the-box were actually pretty good. Setup was quick and easy.According to an online source, the TV (like LG's other 1080P models) has only IPS panels. My TV has the following product code: 42CS570-UD-AUSYLUR. Other online sources stated that the "Y" in the 4th-from-right position indicates an IPS panel.The shipping dimensions (W x H x D) are roughly: 48 inches x 30 inches x 6 inches.I replaced an old 32-inch Panasonic CRT TV. So, obviously this LG HD TV is a noticeable upgrade. That said, I can't really comment on how the screen or engine compares to other HD TVs. I'm receiving over-the-air HD channels through a cheap, GE indoor antenna I've had for years, similar to the 24731. I have my Wii connected through a Monoprice Composite cable. Through a Monoprice HDMI cable, I'm running a Panasonic DMP-BDT220 Blu-ray player I purchased for Blu-ray content, streaming content, and miscellaneous content I have on my Synology DS211J NAS acting as a DLNA server. Just for giggles, I also ran a 25-foot Monoprice VGA cable (with audio) from my laptop to the TV. Everything works as well as expected. Picture is great for all uses. Sound is good as well. With realistic expectations, I haven't run into anything to complain about yet.If you have other hardware to handle "smart" services, or just don't care for those services, and don't care to be on the cutting edge of 3D and LED panels, this is an ideal TV. As a 1080P, 120Hz TV with a good set of inputs, this is a quality HD TV that lists for $100 less than last year's nearly identical model.Obviously, I can't comment on the device's longevity. I've run plenty of test scenarios, but I've only had it for a few days. Time will tell. Advertised warranty is 1 year parts, 1 year labor.For the record, I wanted nothing to do with 3D. I had to consider screen glare. I felt a 42-inch TV best fit my living room layout and I had a budget to meet. For my budget, I preferred 120Hz LCD over 60Hz LED-LCD and I preferred 1080P LCD over 720P plasma. Compare to other 42-inch LG models for price and features.42LM6200 = 42-inch, 3D, 1080P, 120Hz, Smart, LED-LCD TV listed for $1,299.9942LM5800 = 42-inch, 3D, 1080P, 120Hz, LED-LCD (not yet available)42LS5700 = 42-inch, 1080P, 120Hz, Smart, LED-LCD TV listed for $1,099.9942LS3400 = 42-inch, 1080P, 60Hz, LED-LCD TV listed for $719.9942CS560 = 42-inch, 1080P, 60Hz, LCD TV listed for $629.9942PM4700 = 42-inch, 3D, 720P, 600Hz, Smart, plasma TV listed for $699.9942PA4500 = 42-inch, 720P, 600Hz, plasma TV listed for $549.99

Reviews.Title: Excellent TV
Reviews.Author: Tommy J
Reviews.Content: Well, I finally broke down and bought an LCD tv. After studying LCDs for about a year. I decided against WIFI in a tv. The problem is keeping a wifi tv updated with current apps. It seems that due to models rapid changes that most TV companies do not wish to spend the resources to keep old models (probably discontinued) updated. So the best option is to save the money abd add a Roku to handle the wifi apps. Roku automatically updates as necessary. I have had a Roku for a few years and they are rock solid.I have presently an old 37 tube type tv. It has been a good tv but it is hopelessly outdated. Now the only problem I have is getting someone to remove it (it weighs a ton) and dispose of it. It still works but it is not a digital tv (got to have the "box" for conversion) or in my case Direct TV..I also, didn't want a 3D TV. 1. I get headaches watching a neighbor's 3D. 2. 3D movies (mostly cartoons)are hokey expensive refurbs (~30-50 bucks). 3. The glasses are expensive. Also, I didn't want the super-duper "easy" controller. Most of these things are a pain. So why waste the money?The LG 570 is very well designed and the menus are easy to navigate. Most are for fine tuning if that is your bag. Me, I plugged it in ran the basic setup time zone, picture, and etc. It works great. I plug in the Roku and wow,, beautiful picture. The remote is well laid out and logical. I dislike those "control" everything remotes as they are a major pain to set up and only halfway work.Just a suggestion on unpacking. When messing with LCDs never touch the screen. I turned the box upside down edgewise. carefully cut the tape. Open the flaps tape them open if necessary. Turn the box top side up edgewise. Then simply left the box off while holding the TV. Now carefully study the stand installation in the included manual. There is an extra part (dust cover) which is installed when wall mounting the TV. It covers up the hole the table stand is installed in.The screws are in the bag the manual was in. I wouldn't use a power screw driver. Gently tighten each screw when all the other screws are installed. I propped the TV up by the backside. In my opinion it is not a good idea to lay it screen down even if the surface looks flat. The two table stand parts fit perfectly together. Attach four screws and snug them down. If you have to force the parts you have them wrong. Then drop the stand into the mount hole on TV. Of course the wide part of stand is to the front of TV. Install and snug four screws.I downloaded the full manual (about 70 pages)from the LG tech support website. Note; When searching the model number leave off LG letters. There is a ton of features available explained in the big manual. The included manual is just a bare bones getting started type..I got a handyman coming over take out the old TV (too heavy for me and my bad knee). Then I can hook up surround sound (fiber optic connection). There is no analog sound output. There is an input button on the top of the remote that brings up the input screen. Only those inputs that are active are selected. Also, you can create labels for the inputsI tried out a USB dongle with a ton of pictures. The folder navigator works good. There is a Vista type picture player that pops up when you select a picture and then you can do a slide show. Works very smooth.Ye Gods, 42 inches is HUGE. My first TV (cost about $1000 in today's money) was a 19 inch Admiral (that was a big one in 1950). Hey, 20 yrs before I had a "cat whisker" crystal radio. Grandpa said I was crazy to spend that kind of money on a silly box that was just a "fad". He sure enjoyed the old "Oprey" on the "fad".The local antenna input has an automatic scanner that picks out the "good"signal channels. It takes a bit of time in the Phoenix area. Just be patient. Geezz,I didn't realize how many digital channels there are. You may have to go back and delete some. The Quick menu is fast for deletes and adding. Note: when local antenna is hooked up no signal will be present until the scan is completed.I will do updates as time goes by. So far I LOVE IT!!!!Update (next day):  AUDIOWell, hooking up the surround sound (7 speakers )was a learning experience. Hooking up the fiber optic cable is a lot easier if you remember to remove the dust covers on each end of the cable (Amazon has them cheap). The sound is incredibly crystal clear. I knew there was loss in the analog cables, but I had no idea it was that much! Wow!! The Bose speakers came alive. I could blow out the windows at half power. My ears would probably go first. So I was careful with the sound level.A big problem with a audio optic output is that there is no volume control on the source. The sound level is controlled only by the speaker power amp. But the crystal clear sound is worth the inconvenience.When using my DirectTV box there was no optical output so I ran the cable (yellow, red white)into AV1 on the TV. I put the Ruko on HDMi 1. Every thing worked great.Now back to the sound level problem: The TV in house speakers are good (not great)but the sound volume control on remote works good. I have a 19 LCD tv and it had terrible speakers so I installed a Logitech computer sound system with bass unit(Amazon) plugged into the headphone jack on TV. Problem solved.As the LG has a headphone jack, I may do the same.Tune the Direct TV to ch 802 power up the surround sound the 1950's Doo Wop rocks (best music ever written of course Glenn Miller and Neil Diamond are close). The bass box rattles the windows. I mute the sound on the TV kick back and let the Malt shop memories flood back (News Flash: To all male younguns out there: Girls are predators and always have been)!Now I am going to dump my old DVD player and get one with optical output.Update:The Direct TV programming code for DTV remote is 10178.The DTV remote programming is in the system menu. You hold down the mute and select buttons until the TV light (move selector to TV) on Remote blinks 3 times. Then enter code. The sound button on DTV remote should popup the volume level indicator on TV screen. If so move the selector back to DTV and you are in business.New Update:  The in house speakers are so, so. I took the logictech computer speaker system and plugged them into the TV phone jack. Much better sound. The bass unit is really good.PROBLEM: When you plug into head phone jack the fiber optic  sound output cuts off. RATS, why did they do that? I wanted leave the computer speakers in and still be able to use the surround sound system for Netflix. So I am stuck with the cheapy in house speakers. The audio features are not well thought out...If you don't need the fiber optic audio out. Then get Logitech speakers with bass unit. They sound MUCH better than the in house speakers...

Reviews.Title: beautiful
Reviews.Author: Terri Junk
Reviews.Content: just received my new tv - once you turn off the energy saver it has a beautiful picture.  energy saver made the picture go very dark.  easy to put together and the owners manual CD is very detailed and made set up easy.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic TV ... with only one possible issue.
Reviews.Author: Miggy "Miggy, the Thief"
Reviews.Content: I'm stilling giving the TV 5 stars, because the TV itself is fantastic. The picture is beautiful after calibration, and with energy saver mode turned off, obviously. I found that the TruMotion feature works under certain conditions, mostly for TV broadcasts. For DVD and Bluray, I had to turn it off - because, even though it did seem to make the image appear sharper (especially for DVD material), I just couldn't get used to the SOE. Suddenly, the Mentalist characters looked like they wandered onto the set of Days of Our Lives. Just too distracting.Anyway, my only possibly issue involves the stand. I don't know if this is normal or if I got a stand that's somehow defective. To put it simply, the TV wobbles. It's okay as it sits there and doesn't lean in any direction. But if I have to touch it to clean it or plug in a USB drive, I have to grab hold of a corner to keep it still. I took the stand apart and put it together again to make sure I tightened the screws adequately (I had originally worried about that, due to the fact the instructions said not to tighten them too much). After tightening it as much as I could by hand, the wobble still remained. The only thing I noticed unusual was when screwing the base into the TV itself. The bottom right screw had to be screwed in all the way from the outside of the cabinet, but the left bottom screw "fell" into the hole without having to be tightened first. I could still screw it in tight from where it "landed", but could it be missing some of its hold because of this? Just sitting on the stand, which it is 99% of the time, the TV is fine. I just wonder if it needs a replacement stand.Otherwise, I love the TV and it was a perfect fit for me, as I was not interested in having a "smart TV" and the 3D ones I've tried out at Best Buy give me a headache.UPDATE: I contacted LG support for the stand issue and they said it sounded like a defective stand. They sent out a new one. Their support was outstanding, responsive, and I received the part within days. Unfortunately, the bottom left screw still fell into the hole and the TV is still wobbly. It must be a problem with the screw hole on the TV. So I am going to live with the wobble rather than go to the trouble of returning the TV, as well as risking (with my luck) getting a replacement TV that has some issue with the display itself.

Reviews.Title: The size and the price were right for me
Reviews.Author: Music Lover
Reviews.Content: I just purchased this TV after my 34" Sony HDTV's (tube) power supply went out. I was ready to get rid of it anyway since it was a 200lb. monster but it had such a good picture that I hated to part with it.I had been watching TV prices for the past 6 months or more on Amazon and elsewhere. I had read numerous reviews of various models and wanted to purchase a TV that would fit in the 40" space I have that would not cost an arm and a leg. I thought about all the various options including Internet access which I would love to have, the quality of picture on LCD, LED and Plasma's and thought about 3D a little bit. I decided what I really wanted was a great picture at a reasonable price and this model won out. It seems like Internet connectivity is almost refined now but I can live without it. I can definately live without 3D TV for now.I didn't go to a big box store to look at any models but I was comfortable I knew what I was doing after reading everything I could find online the last 6 months. I knew the style that I wanted and this LG is pretty handsome for a 42" HDTV.I really wanted the Panasonic Plasma GT50 and still do but it is very expensive. After reading all the reviews I fell in love with it but I had to be practical and scale back my desires due to the cost. Since this LG was less than half the price of the GT50 and it fit into my space so I bought this model.I wanted 1080P and had to decide between LCD and LED. I also considered the LG 50" Plasma model PA6500 which is only about a $100 more than this model. It has gotten really good reviews and is approximately half the price of the GT50.I am very picky and waned the best bang for my lesser buck. I searched the various brands and stores and decided on this model, had it delivered and the big Sony taken away. The 570 looks good where it sits. Its simple design is sharp looking and functional and is fairly easy to set-up. You can manually swivel the screen which is nice if you are the only person watching TV you can move it towards you.I was thinking Samsung LED or and LG LED also but since the LED's are more expensive I went LCD. This is my first LCD and it is going to take some getting used to. I enjoyed the picture on my tube but it was too small. The 42" is big and just about the right size for my living room. We sit about 5-6 feet away from the TV.The settings on this TV are fairly easy to navigate thru. I took the energy saving feature off and then played with the picture settings for quite a few days until I was comfortable with what I was looking at. I tried the various modes which you can tweak to your personal taste. I settled on the Cinema picture mode and manually adjusted the settings to my taste. I have also thought about calibrating the picture which I pretty much did myself but would love to find the perfect settings in an online forum. If anyone sees this info anywhere please let everyone know.The sound quality is good. Separate Bass and Treble settings and a Clearvoice feature sound pretty good. There are 3 or 4 audio settings to choose from.I like the TV for the price and hope to learn to love it more as time goes on. All in all I am comfortable with my purchase and the functionality of the CS570.

Reviews.Title: I'll always buy LG products from now on.
Reviews.Author: M. MCCLURE
Reviews.Content: I've become fed up with buying electronics that have pages & pages of instructions about how to operate them. "User friendly" used to be a goal of developers. I am so happy to have found LG products because they are easy to set up and use right away. I plugged this TV in and it guided me through some simple steps to get it going and running ROKU. It was so very easy. It's been about a month now and it remains a joy to use. I later bought a LG Blu-ray disc player and once again it was easily mated to the TV and running with a few simple steps. Finally,truly user-friendly machines. The remotes for the tv & disc player can be used almost interchangeably, so there's only one remote needed most of the time. I don't have a single complaint. I would like to have the mute button work in 2 stages, but that's a minor thing. Right now, it's an either-or mute, and sometimes it's nice to just take the sound down halfway.

Reviews.Title: Great Large Form Factor LCD TV for the Money
Reviews.Author: Bruce Lyon
Reviews.Content: I ended up not buying my LG from Amazon because I wanted to avoid the shipping company abuse and my local electronics store, PC Richards, had the same TV for the same money. Yeah, I would have saved sales tax buying it on Amazon but being able to have the TV tested in the store then being able to control it's shipping to my house 8 miles away was worth the little extra expense to me.I replaced my little 28" Hannspree LCD LCD so going from 28" to 47" was a big, beautiful jump in screen size. The LG 47CS570 had the 1080P and the 120Hz refresh rate I was looking for. The only thing I also wanted was LED back lighting but for this size TV, having that back lighting over the older Fluorescent back-lighting was too much extra expense for the money. The 47CS570 has a great picture only jumping from the little Hannspee to the large LG really shows how much worse 480p is from 1080i or 1080p. On the smaller set, the lower resolution did not really show, on the bigger set, it shows up in a big way and I have trouble tolerating standard definition now on the larger set. Thankfully, my cable company has an HD station alternative for all the old SD stations I used to watch. I've had good luck with LG products so let this void out some of the others who trash LG. This is a very nice set and for less than $800, it is a great buy.

Reviews.Title: nice tv
Reviews.Author: Ann B
Reviews.Content: We bought the lg for the bedroom.  the picture on the LG is fantastic. the only complaint is the same as ones I have read about this tv. It has an energy saver mode that makes the picture slowly dim as you are watching it.  Simple solution is to turn off the energy saver mode and you will have a terrific picture.

Reviews.Title: Why pay more
Reviews.Author: ACMILANNY
Reviews.Content: An amazing picture at great price, from a quality company. Cant beat that. Sound is not bad at all either. Highly recommended

Reviews.Title: Use reviews correctly
Reviews.Author: Lisa
Reviews.Content: Please review the specific model not just the brand.  I've had LG for years and have been very happy.  Just writing a review to dump on the brand not evaluate this particular model isn't helping the other customers like myself make a decision.

Reviews.Title: Wow
Reviews.Author: James
Reviews.Content: I am seriously impressed with the quality of this TV.  I game primarily with it and the graphics are just outstanding, if you are going to be gaming I would highly suggest getting nothing lower than 120 HTZ.  At 60 HTZ I noticed that the game play would not be smooth and vary "lagy" .  I would recommend this product to anyone, truly unbeatable price as well.  Also within the first three months of owning it, the screen started to turn of and on randomly without doing anything to it, and it got to the point were it would not stay on at all.  I called up LG told them of my problem they were extremely helpful,  the TV being under warranty they sent a technician out without question. When the tech came out he replaced both of the boarding in the TV because it was under warranty and told me this problem to be vary rare. After this experience with the company I don't think I will ever buy any other brand of TV again.  The last thing i wanted to do was send my TV in to some repair depo and have no idea when I would be getting it back. SATISFIED

Reviews.Title: LG 47" great tv.
Reviews.Author: Justin Merritt
Reviews.Content: I bought this 47" TV about a month and a half ago. It works fine, the quality is amazing, but it seems that the volume is kinda iffy. From volume level 20-40, or so, there's hardly a difference in the sound output while watching TV ( but you know the commercials are loud :b). However, when playing video games the sound acts as normal. Regardless though, that's the only issue I've encountered so far. I had standard shipping and it was delivered on the second day after it was purchased. I would recommend this seller to a friend or family member.

Reviews.Title: Best of its class
Reviews.Author: Raul Torres-ruiz "Raul Torres"
Reviews.Content: Crispy image, great sound!  This TV is completely worth its prize.  Don't settle for a cheaper LCD thinking they are all the same.

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: Kevin
Reviews.Content: Great TV, Great Price, Great Features.  Exactly what I was looking for.  I was even impressed with the internal speakers - they are great for LCD tv.  I still bought some computer speakers to use too.  Everything works great so far.

Reviews.Title: Great picture
Reviews.Author: C. Leeds
Reviews.Content: An absolute great picture. Bought the LG 42" from Amazon and the same day bought a 60" Samsung for three time the price from Best Buy. The picture on the LG is better that the Samsung and the Samsung is very good. I would buy another LG if I needed another TV.

Reviews.Title: I love this TV, trouble with PC connect
Reviews.Author: Peter D.
Reviews.Content: So far, this is probably one of the best Tv's I've ever purchased. I bought a 32" LG about 2 years ago and loved it. However, I went abroad soon after for about a year so I left it to my parents. When I got back they were not willing to give it up. I started doing some research and purchased this TV about a month ago. I decided to upgrade to a 42" but stick with the LG brand since I liked my 32" so much. My first reaction was this thing is HUGE but after staring at a 20" TV for almost 6 months that is probably a normal response.Picture:Picture quality is great on this TV, the colors are excellent and I really like the no blur motion. At first it through me off, after so many years of watching TV and having moving objects blur across the screen. I like to watch a lot of action movies so this was definitely a cool feature that made everything seem more real. Also great for video gaming since there is a lot of motion with the characters while playing.Menus and settings:Menus and setting adjusting is easy to use. There is a very detailed picture adjustment function that lets you set all the colors to your liking. It is fairly easy to switch back and forth between component, HDMI and cable which is not always the case with TVs.Connecting ports:One of the biggest things for me is that there is a PC connection since I like to connect my computer to the TV. While looking for TV I noticed that many of the lower end models no longer have this feature. I was annoyed when my DVI to VGA cable would not work with this TV. Although I was able to find a HDMI to DVI on amazon for cheap it was an added aggravation and expense.Price:Budget was an issue for me but I was not willing to sacrifice quality. That is where I think this TV is great. Trying to find a reliable brand with solid 1080P picture quality, 120 HZ for a good price is not easy.Overall:I am reluctant to give this TV 5 stars due to the hassle with the HDMI cable however this TV delivers on all fronts (plus the cool no blur.) I highly recommend it and I definitely will not be lending it to my parents any time soon.

Reviews.Title: Great TV
Reviews.Author: John W. Chan
Reviews.Content: I had bought an LG smart TV model 32LD550 that is a 32 inch and like it very much. It was simple to use, user friendly, great color and contrast. My main use for it is gaming and tv show watching. So it promote me to buy another LG for the living room. I have search on amazon for sometime, comparing to other brands, model and researching for the right size to fit in my living room. After much searching I finally came across this LG model 47CS570 much like my little 32 inch but bigger and almost have the same features but the netcast. I'm please with it, it was easy to set up, connect up and with USB port watching shows, movies on a flash drive is great. Next on list is surround sound.

Reviews.Title: 47 inch LG HGTV
Reviews.Author: Monique D. Graver "Pooh"
Reviews.Content: 2 Days old and I am delighted and amazed with the quality and vivid colors.I am glad that I purchased this item. Only negative-No output for audio (i.e., Sound bar)

Reviews.Title: Fabulous tv
Reviews.Author: jane
Reviews.Content: Nothing too fancy here, just a good tv with a great picture. I wasn't looking for a lot of bells and whistles. Picture is fine off angle as well. Highly recommend.

Reviews.Title: LG = Looks Great!
Reviews.Author: The Wise Owl
Reviews.Content: I finally treated myself to a bedroom Television after many years of thinking it wouldn't be a good idea to lay in bed while watching hours of TV.I'm so glad I had a change of mind.That said, I should send my electric bill to LG !This is a superlative product.The 42 inch was the perfect size for viewing from bed across the room.The picture quality is outstanding and once you turn off a few of the options as others have mentioned, all works divinely. ( Energy saver, off. Motion, off)I happen to the love the sound quality even though others have complained it isn't strong enough. I don't need the extra speakers or extra loud volume.The set up was easy, even though it's relatively heavy, I was able to lift it onto the stand by myself.The price was fantastic! These sets have come down over the years making them far more affordable for multiple rooms.My advice: Go for it!Enjoy the luxury for the money!

Reviews.Title: NICE
Reviews.Author: WillyNH
Reviews.Content: This TV is a steal for people seeking the best picture quality for the price.Remember this is a LCD TV - LCD TV's offer good value given at a lower price, doing so with above average picture quality. LED TVs have more advanced technology, slightly better picture quality (generally speaking), but comes at a higher price point.I personally wouldn't build my home entertainment system around this TV but its more than adequate for a man cave, bedroom or den.

Reviews.Title: Amazing - Updated 5/29
Reviews.Author: S. Vusirikala
Reviews.Content: Pros:I bought it for 450 from a cat named store on a recent deal.The screen is semi-matte which was a huge bonus way beyond what I expected.The sound is loud, clear, has bass, and does not sound like it's coming from an LCD TV.The motion smoothing is way better than some other brands out there, and also allows you to control dejudder and deblur separately.The TV looks ridiculously good in my living room. It is just the right size for an apartment living room.The stand is very well engineered.Fit together well.If you have an LG Blu-Ray player, there is a simplink button that will turn it on and automatically switch to that source and you can also control the bluray player from the TV remote. Happy accident :)Edit: Forgot this pro: very thoughtful of LG. The menu has settings on what to do with the power/standby LED. I have disabled the LED for power, and enabled it for standby. I know when the TV is on, duh! Since I turn off the power strip to save power, I want to know when the TV is on standby vs. when the power strip is on. Very thoughtful to include this setting. I returned a P50UT50 for a different reason, but it had an LED that would be on when the TV is on. Is that dumb or what?ConsSource switching is a bit painful. But I think I will figure out a way in time. I've only had the TV a day.Simplink does not bring you back to what you were watching when you get out. It also does not turn off the blu ray player.Overall, I am very happy though. Especially with the matte screen and sound.--------------------------------Update 5/29/13:I am still kind of shocked at the value I got this TV for. We made a trip to Michigan over the weekend, came home, plugged a USB flash drive, and ran a photo slideshow. The interface is  nothing fancy but the colors were ridiculous. The other day I found myself watching Castle on TNT (worst written show ever!) just because of how good the picture looked. I've been watching Cardinals BB games for the last two months and it's perfect for those as well. I haven't messed with the settings much. I recently switched to AT&T; U-verse and am pleased to report that like my Dish remote before, the uverse remote can fully control the TV including input switching. I did the auto search and skipped the first match and ran to the second match. The first match would work for volume and power, but only the second match was able to switch inputs. With a new version out, I would expect this to be snaggable for $350-$400 in the near future. And it is definitely a good value.

Reviews.Title: Great purchase for price
Reviews.Author: Paul Slack
Reviews.Content: The size of the TV is perfect for my living room. Colors are vibrant and picture is crisp...especially after switching cable companies to Verizon FIOS. Sports and movies alike look fantastic on this set. The options are nice including the expert controls for fine tuning the setting (picture settings). The remote is just ok....there could be more option functionality on it. Reviews.Title: A great TV with a great picture!

Reviews.Content: This is a wonderful TV that I had my eye on for 2 years.  Finally pulled the trigger and I'm in love!

Reviews.Title: LG 42" TV
Reviews.Author: Brian Graham-Moore
Reviews.Content: Bright, sharp picture with lots of options to change it.  It does all the things it is supposed to do.  The only thing I don't like is the stand since we are not mounting this TV on the wall.  It seems lightweight.

Reviews.Title: LG 47" 1080p 120hz
Reviews.Author: Eleven bang bang
Reviews.Content: UPDATE: After having this tv for 40 days, it failed on me. All it does now is come on for about 30 seconds and shut right back off. I sent it back to Amazon is hopes of a full refund even know it is just outside the 30 day full return window. I would still recommend you buy an extended warranty with any large purchase you get off of here.Just bought this tv a week ago and so far I love it.  The picture is great and it's just the right size for my living room. One thing I do dislike about the tv is the trumotion feature LG put on there, in my opinion the picture looks better with this turned off.  The trumotion is suppose to help smooth out the motion blur, but it appears to make it worse.  Overall, great bang for the buck.

Reviews.Title: I month past warranty TV snapped and died.
Reviews.Author: Gracie86
Reviews.Content: While it worked, this LG TV had great picture quality and better than decent sound.  I purchased on June 9, 2012 and took delivery on June 17th.  Today, just a little over a year later, it was on and all was fine.  And then - a pop and nothing but a black screen and the sound of static.  The screen does not show any logo or menus.  The cable box tries to connect and I get a few seconds of the sound of static, then back to black silence.There are many videos on how to repair this by soldering capacitors on an internal panel.  Soldering is not my forté.  So I am left with a non-working TV in an area where there is no local LG service and I am out of warranty.  NOT happy.UPDATE 7/28/13LG has the WORST warranty repair service EVER.  They did put the TV back under warranty but this is useless as they say they do not have anyone within 100 miles of me to do the repairs.  I do not live in SIBERIA, for crying out loud.  I live in Waupaca, WI, which is 35 miles from Appleton and Stevens Point, both major hubs with every chain store that exists in America represented in each.  Really?  NO ONE can get to my house to repair this piece of junk?UPDATE 8/15/13So LG found a repair tech in Appleton but they have not sent the part I need, after 3 (count 'em THREE) boxes of parts to this shop and 2 weeks of waiting.  Still without a TV.DO NOT PURCHASE FROM LG...unless you can afford to completely replace their malfunctioning products after a year as NO ONE will be available to fix them.

Reviews.Author: YOO, Y.
Reviews.Content: I ordered a new tv but the one we've received was definitely not new. It was missing one of the screws on the side and thus had a gap between the screen and the body of the tv. Not only is the tv in bad condition, it was also missing a stand body for the assembly. The box for this has been opened before we've received it because the bottom of the box was open and the styrofoam protecting the tv was missing for the top part. Reviews.Title: Fantastic TV!
Reviews.Author: Bill S.
Reviews.Content: I purchased this TV online on 11/23/12 from Walmart.com; and, with free shipping, it was delivered 6 days later on 11/29/12. I researched this TV for 2 months and I couldn't be any happier with my decision. The picture is incredibly good and, with the Surround Sound turned on, it takes TV viewing to a whole different level. I am a huge sports fan; so I set the Picture mode to Sport, the TruMotion to high, turned off the Energy Saving option, and tweaked the Advanced settings until I had an incredibly good picture. I also set the Audio Mode to Sport, and turned off the Clear Voice option because the Surround Sound only works with the clear voice off. I can't understand why some people have complained about the volume. I have the TV connected to a Cablevision high definition cable box using an HDMI cable that was supplied for free by Cablevision, and I control the volume using the Cablevision remote. With the volume at 12, it is borderline too loud, and it will go past 50! One bit of advice; the Owner's Manual that is provided with the TV is inadequate (at 35 pages long it is more like a quick start guide). I went to the LG website and downloaded the complete Owner's manual which is 79 pages long and that is what I used to set up my TV. I highly recommend this TV!

Reviews.Title: AWESOME
Reviews.Author: Kelsey
Reviews.Content: Love this TV! Arrived promptly in perfect condition. Volume is fantastic. Display is surreal. I know a lot of people aren't fans of LG's but my parents bought a 55in 1080p 240hz a few years ago and have nothing but wonderful things to say about it. I would have to agree. Ignore all the negative reviews. These are some of the best TVs for the price.

Reviews.Title: Full Power=Great Picture Quality

Reviews.Title: All I can say is... WOW!
Reviews.Author: Louis Leikach "LLinMD"
Reviews.Content: I have to say, my path to the 42CS570 was not straightfowrad.  BTW, I didn't buy this item on Amazon, but that was just because I have a Best Buy less than 2 miles from my house.  I buy a lot of items from Amazon, the biggest, a Broil King grill, but for the TV, the BB was just convenient. Anyway, back to the review.  I bought 2 TVs at the same time, a 55" for the family room (the LG 55LM7600 - which at the time of this writing, I still have not had delivered - by choice), and then I was trying to figure out which set to purchase for the bedroom. I didn't do as much research as I did on the 55", and I sort of paid the price.  I bought a 37" Samsung LED (UN37EH5000) on sale for about $450 - within my price range.  I was still trying to figure out if I liked the set when BB offered the UN39EH5000 for the same price.  I exchanged it. That's when I really started getting into the TV. And I found it lacking. I wasn't happy with how the color washed out and seemed pasty when I wasn't directly in front of it.  A not too sharp angle just left me cold - and my wife too.  I started more indepth research and I think the LED I had is an edge-lit TV.  From what I can tell, the backlit sets are brighter and have less tendency to have the bad angle effect.  I considered exchanging for a plasma - again down to a 43" Samsung and and a 42" LG.  But once I got into the store and saw both sets - I was really put off by the color (whites were pink or grey) and the glassy reflective screens.  I know you have to get past the setups in the stores.  The lighting is all wrong, the room size is unrealistic, yada-yada-yada. But I just couldn't get past what my eyes were seeing.  And after all, when all the specs are read, despite what they say, it's what your eyes discern that makes the TV work for you or not.Back to the drawing board. I believe what I was looking for was a backlit LED with local dimming - but it was just a little out of my price range.  What to do... what to do? I went with a little older technology - an LCD. From all I read, they are reliable and have very decent specs. In the store, it passed my eyeball test.  I just had to wrap my head around not going with the "latest" technology.  I did want 1080p and I did want the 120Hz.  The LG 42CS570 was the set that fit my scaled back goals. All I can say is WOW!. First, it was easier to set up than the Samsung - which itself wasn't too difficult to set up. The Picture Wizard - what can I say.  Easy as pie to set the best settings for my eyes.  And it was the 3rd TV set in a less than 10 day period that I had done it with.  And the picture... and the sound!  I did pay another $50 to upgrade to the 42CS450 - yes... I definitely feel it was an upgrade.  Picture is incredibly clear and the sound has no need for a soundbar or surround sound. Perfect for our bedroom. Sometimes, depending on the type broadcast (I haven't used it for anything but from Verizon Fios source), I get a touch of that soap opera effect you always hear about. To me it's not a detriment - I like it - a lot!  Oh, I did plug in a USB drive with pictures from my daughter's wedding - it was like watching them for the first time.I definitely recommend this TV. If you take my advice, for about $500 - you can't do better.

Reviews.Author: E. Postell "BIG LOOT"
Reviews.Content: I ordered this TV early Friday morning not expecting it until later in the week. To my delight, Saturday morning the Fedex delivery guy was knocking at my door, just in time for playoff football. Not bad considering shipping and handeling was only ¢.99! Setup was a piece of cake. I watched some college basketball (Go Hoyas!) and you could see beads of sweat drip off the players face while he was at the free throw line. The picture is almost too good. I tried the usb port, I'm not sure if I was doing anything wrong but when I plugged in my iphone5 it's not talking to the TV but it does charge. For all the people that have issues with the sound. What are you expecting? It's a flat screen TV, the speakers are in the back. If you don't want to invest in a sound bar, you can always buy the simple red/white audio wire and connect it to a home stereo system. it will sound 10x better. Bottom line. buy this tv especially if you have an xbox or PS3 (because it's not a 'smart TV') and invest in sound if you're buying a flat screen. You will not find higher quality for the price

Reviews.Title: Excellent high quality picture value
Reviews.Author: D. Folk "df"
Reviews.Content: I researched 42cs570, found basically the consumers reports review. My observations:Matte screen: In a ,typical, BRIGHT, room absolutely the way to go over the more normal highly reflective screen. Its worth insisting on this or you will have to fight distracting reflections.Picture quality generally: This unit puts out one of the most"accurate" looking pictures I have seen. Some other tv's  would have some colors that were impressive- basically because they were almost fluorescent- not impressively realistic.Sound:Pretty good. Not Bose surround sound (or whatever).Internet connectivity: It has none -and you probably should not care in the long run. I've been in computers a long time. Checked in with various sources. Turns out that you can get these roku, apple and other set top box's cheap- 65-95 maybe. These are powerful very cheap devices that allow some people to completely turn off their cable or satellite and get all their tv content thru roku using the internet. These are add ons  for any tv. Bottom Line for the long run: Forget about whatever connectivity deal that comes with any tv. Before too long you will own one of these inexpensive- and the main point- continually evolving internet set top boxes. No way that whatever came out in a tv in 2012 will have anything like the capabilities of a set top box (they don't today) and imagine what those boxes will be able to do in a few more years.Overall: Like it a lot so far, really glad I insisted on the matte screen.

Reviews.Title: Great TV!  Love it for HD DVR/BLU RAY/PS3
Reviews.Author: RYAN AMOS
Reviews.Content: Prior to this I had a 37" 1080i 60Hz Insignia in my living room.  I thought it did a good job for Blu Ray movies, HD televison, and Playstation 3 gaming.  Now I know what it was supposed to look and sound like.I did have to take a few minutes to test different settings for both video and sound (there is a voice enhancing feature).  The energy saver feature is a nice touch.  Saving electricity while watching televison or movies in a room with subdued lighting is definitely a plus and it has several levels you can set it to, including "screen off" for music, however, if you are playing HD video games or are watching televion or a movie during daytime with sunlight coming in, you will find the picture rather dark.There is a "True Motion" feature that you can set manually or use Low or High presets that removes blurring and jarring which really makes a big difference when watching "action" shows or sports and especially when playing video games.The sound is great and has a "auto volume" feature for those who hate watching a movie that you have to constantly turn the volume up when people are talking just to immediately turn it down 20 notches because Bruce Willis is suddenly getting shot at...  Also the "Clear Voice" feature is great for television shows where conversation is key (e.g. Bones, The Mentalist, Big Bang Theory, etc.)This is a great product.

Reviews.Title: Wow you will love this tv
Reviews.Author: Lynda J. Labine
Reviews.Content: When my Mitsubishi in my bedroom died I decided to get a " smart tv " putting gimmicks over a clean, clear, bright display.  Bought a Samsung 40ES6100...what a gigantic mistake...my bedroom is very bright so the reflective screen made watching tv during the day a challenge. the Smart hub was stupid and clunky...the LED made everything blue and murky...i had to turn up everything to get a decent picture clouding was everywhere...after six weeks of tweaking I could not stand the white flash lighting from the edge lit tv and returned it...I purchased the LG42CS570....right out of the box it was beautiful.  No clouding or banding ..colors that were vibrant and beautiful ...I could actually see a great picture even on the sunniest days...I connected a toshiba sound bar and a Sony Blueray player  with built in wifi so it became a smart tv...if you are someone who wants to tweak your set to perfection there are tons of settings to do this..I simply love this set so much that I chose the 47 inch for my living room...guess what...same glorious picture...it connected right up to my surround receiver giving me the theater experience I wanted.  Yes the stand is a little wobbly but it still feels solid enough...I think this is a non problem ..both of my new sets are IPS panels so offside viewing is excellent ....my only concern is the talk of these tvs going off and on by themselves but I got extended warranties in case that happens.  The trumotion is cool for shows like "the amazing race" gives a 3D effect that is jaw dropping.you can tweak that because it gives you three settings to do this including user  which I can turn down to a minimum...In conclusion I got just what I paid for on these two sets...a crisp clear picture with true colors and an even lighting display...whites that are white...blacks that aren't crushed...I know there are some who think LED Smart tvs with edge lighting is the way to go and LCDs is a step backward but I can't disagree more...I may change my mind but right now I am just enjoying watching tv something that I did not do for the time I had the Samsung....I was too preoccupied trying to fix the picture on that set and looking at the flash lighting..for now I am completely satisfied...these sets are going fast so if you are on the fence don't hesitate

Reviews.Title: It's the great value all of the other reviews say it is...
Reviews.Author: jlil
Reviews.Content: I got the 47" LG about two weeks ago for $550 and we've watched a movie every night since it arrived.  The picture is so clear and vivid, that it almost looks 3D (which blew me away but messed w/ my wife's eyes).  I went from a 37" Sharp Aquos w/ 720p and 60Hz (which I thought had a pretty good picture) to the LG and I couldn't believe how drastic the difference in picture quality was.  The first few days I caught myself saying "wow" under my breath as I watched a hockey or basketball game.  Oh, and I can finally see the difference between a DVD and a Blu-ray; they had always looked the same to me on our old TV.  And, as others have said, make sure you turn off the eco mode.  If it's left on the picture will be way too dark in a well lit room.  All in all, I think if you pay less than $600 for this TV, you're getting a heck of a value and more than your money's worth.

Reviews.Title: Motion Blur.
Reviews.Author: Lewis
Reviews.Content: Price: good. Physical appearance: Great. Picture: Not so great. Here is the issue. I am not exactly sure what terms they use for this but based on what I've read it's called motion blur and it sucks. It seems like what is happenening is when a person moves accross the screen the picture (or the "information" as far as the processor is concerned) is not rebuilding fast enough to look normal. In other words, I see an outine around the figure that looks like a mess of blocky, blurry pixels. Its especially noticable when a dark figure moves accross a light background. The tv is advertised as one with a high number of hertz which would eliminate the blur but I find this to be untrue and false advertising. It seems less problematic with the newer films but with the older ones, especially on dvd, it is very distracting. Besides this the picture is great. When things are moving slow or the figures on the screen are still, it looks great. I would look for a plasma or another model from LG.
